importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news article, indicating when the flooding event's death toll and response measures were officially reported and communicated to the public.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe during which the heavy rains and flooding occurred, highlighting the recent and ongoing disaster situation in Mexico.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding across five states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing, with the highest numbers in Veracruz and Hidalgo.
Veracruz confirmed 29 deaths, Hidalgo 21, Puebla 13, and Queretaro 1.
Forty-three people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and four in Puebla.
Thousands of military troops, including Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to assist with emergency response and aid distribution.
Around 100,000 homes were affected, with some areas experiencing complete destruction due to floods and landslides.
The heavy rainfall was linked to the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond.
The heaviest rains were recorded in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
Nearly 400 repair workers restored over 80% of electricity supply to affected areas, where about 263,000 users lost power.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated that no prior meteorological warnings indicated the magnitude of the rainfall, raising questions about early warning systems in Mexico.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In Mexico, heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused severe flooding across five states, resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. Veracruz, Hidalgo, and Puebla were the most affected, with 29, 21, and 13 deaths respectively. The National Civil Protection Coordination, under chief Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported widespread destruction, with over 100,000 homes impacted and many roads blocked by landslides. Despite emergency military deployment and extensive aid efforts, the government acknowledged a lack of prior warning signs, raising concerns about the effectiveness of Mexico’s early alert systems. Recovery efforts, including electricity restoration, have progressed significantly, with nearly 80% of power restored to affected areas.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
